mn26:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn26:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
mn26:2.2: Then several bhikkhus went up to Venerable Ānanda and said to him,
mn26:2.3: “Friend, it’s been a long time since we’ve heard a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.
mn26:2.4: It would be good if we got to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”
mn26:2.5: “Well then, friends, go to the brahmin Rammaka’s hermitage.

mn26:3.4: So the Buddha went with Ānanda to the Eastern Monastery.
mn26:3.5: In the late afternoon the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed Ānanda,

mn26:3.8: So the Buddha went with Ānanda to the eastern gate to bathe.
mn26:3.9: When he had bathed and emerged from the water he stood in one robe drying himself.
mn26:3.10: Then Ānanda said to the Buddha,
mn26:3.11: “Bhante, the hermitage of the brahmin Rammaka is nearby.
mn26:3.14: It would be good if the Blessed One went to the hermitage of the brahmin Rammaka out of compassion.”

mn26:5.1: Bhikkhus, there are these two quests:
mn26:5.2: the noble quest and the ignoble quest.
mn26:5.3: And what is the ignoble quest?
mn26:5.4: It’s when someone who is themselves subject to birth seeks what is also subject to birth. Themselves subject to age, they seek what is also subject to aging. Themselves subject to illness, they seek what is also subject to illness. Themselves subject to death, they seek what is also subject to death. Themselves subject to sorrow, they seek what is also subject to sorrow. Themselves subject to defilement, they seek what is also subject to defilement.
mn26:6.1: And what should be described as subject to birth?
mn26:6.2: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants and cattle, and gold and money are subject to birth.
mn26:6.3: These acquisitions are subject to birth.
mn26:6.4: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and has fallen for such things, themselves subject to birth, seeks what is also subject to birth.
mn26:7.1: And what should be described as subject to age?
mn26:7.2: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants and cattle, and gold and money are subject to age.
mn26:7.3: These acquisitions are subject to age.
mn26:7.4: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and has fallen for such things, themselves age, seeks what is also subject to age.
mn26:8.1: And what should be described as subject to illness?
mn26:8.2: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and elephants and cattle are subject to illness.
mn26:8.3: These acquisitions are subject to illness.
mn26:8.4: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and has fallen for such things, themselves subject to illness, seeks what is also subject to illness.
mn26:9.1: And what should be described as subject to death?
mn26:9.2: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and elephants and cattle are subject to death.
mn26:9.3: These acquisitions are subject to death.
mn26:9.4: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and has fallen for such things, themselves subject to death, seeks what is also subject to death.
mn26:10.1: And what should be described as subject to sorrow?
mn26:10.2: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and elephants and cattle are subject to sorrow.
mn26:10.3: These acquisitions are subject to sorrow.
mn26:10.4: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and has fallen for such things, themselves subject to sorrow, seeks what is also subject to sorrow.
mn26:11.1: And what should be described as subject to defilement?
mn26:11.2: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants and cattle, and gold and money are subject to defilement.
mn26:11.3: These acquisitions are subject to defilement.
mn26:11.4: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and has fallen for such things, themselves subject to defilement, seeks what is also subject to defilement.
mn26:12.1: And what is the noble quest?
mn26:12.2: It’s when someone who is themselves subject to birth, understanding the danger in being subject to birth, seeks that which is birthless, the supreme safety from the yoke, Nibbāna. Themselves subject to age, illness, death, sorrow, and defilement, understanding the danger in being subject to these things, they seek that which is ageless, free from illness, deathless, sorrowless, and free from defilement, the supreme safety from the yoke, Nibbāna.
mn26:13.1: Bhikkhus, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too, being subject to birth, sought what is also subject to birth. Myself subject to aging, illness, death, sorrow, and defilement, I sought what is also subject to these things.
mn26:13.3: ‘Why do I, being subject to birth, aging, illness, death, sorrow, and defilement seek things that have the same nature?
mn26:13.4: Why don’t I seek that which is birthless, ageless, free from illness, deathless, sorrowless, and free from defilement, the supreme safety from the yoke, Nibbāna?’

mn26:33.7: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation without being tied, infatuated, or attached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape. You should understand that they
mn26:33.8: haven’t met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One cannot do what he wants with them.
mn26:34.1: Suppose there was a wild deer wandering in the forest that walked, stood, sat, and laid down in confidence.
mn26:34.3: Because it’s out of the hunter’s range.
mn26:34.4: In the same way, a bhikkhu, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn26:34.5: This is called a bhikkhu who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.
mn26:35.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a bhikkhu enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn26:35.2: This is called a bhikkhu who has blinded Māra …
mn26:36.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a bhikkhu enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
mn26:36.2: This is called a bhikkhu who has blinded Māra …
mn26:37.1: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a bhikkhu enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
mn26:37.2: This is called a bhikkhu who has blinded Māra …
mn26:38.1: Furthermore, a bhikkhu, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
mn26:38.2: This is called a bhikkhu who has blinded Māra …
mn26:39.1: Furthermore, a bhikkhu, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
mn26:39.2: This is called a bhikkhu who has blinded Māra …
mn26:40.1: Furthermore, a bhikkhu, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
mn26:40.2: This is called a bhikkhu who has blinded Māra …
mn26:41.1: Furthermore, a bhikkhu, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn26:41.2: This is called a bhikkhu who has blinded Māra …
mn26:42.1: Furthermore, a bhikkhu, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.
mn26:42.2: This is called a bhikkhu who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.
mn26:42.3: They’ve crossed over clinging to the world. And they walk, stand, sit, and lie down in confidence.
mn26:42.5: Because they’re out of the Wicked One’s range.”
mn26:42.6: That is what the Buddha said.
mn26:42.7: Satisfied, the bhikkhus approved what the Buddha said.
